revised_title: The Impact of Intracellular Sodium Accumulation on Motor Nerve Endings
tldr: The authors investigated the effects of varying extracellular ion concentrations on digoxin-treated motor nerve endings. They found that reducing sodium concentration delayed the increase in end-plate potential amplitude and miniature end-plate potential frequency, while increasing potassium concentration reduced the time to conduction blockade. The results suggest that intracellular sodium accumulation and loss of potassium play a significant role in the behavior of motor nerve endings treated with digoxin.
